query: What are the most effective management practices on farmland for increasing butterfly and moth abundance?
relevant_summary: Based on the action documents, several farmland management practices have been shown to increase butterfly and moth abundance. Converting to organic farming (Action 3907) demonstrates that organic arable farms had greater abundance of butterflies, burnet moths, and all moths than conventionally managed farms, with butterfly abundance increasing with time since conversion to organic management. Providing or retaining set-aside areas (Action 3980) shows that sown set-aside had higher abundance of butterflies and day-flying moths than cereal fields, especially when sown with less competitive grasses. Planting nectar flower mixtures and wildflower strips (Action 3932) resulted in higher abundance of all butterflies, generalist butterflies, specialist butterflies and meadow brown butterflies than conventional field margins, unsown margins, cropped fields, and conventional grassland. Sowing uncropped arable field margins with native wildflower seed mix (Action 19) supported higher abundance of foraging bumblebees than cropped field edges, grassy margins or naturally regenerated margins. Managing hedgerows to benefit wildlife (Action 3975) found that hedgerows cut once every 2-3 years, cut in autumn, or cut to allow incremental growth had higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths than hedgerows cut to the same size every winter. Planting new hedges (Action 3976) showed that abundance of butterflies, moths, and macro-moths was higher along hedgerows than on beetle banks, grass margins without hedgerows, or in field interiors. Increasing or maintaining natural or semi-natural habitat in farmed landscapes (Action 3910) resulted in higher abundance of butterflies and moths on farms with greater proportion of semi-natural habitat compared to conventional farmland. Reducing fertilizer, pesticide or herbicide use generally (Action 3897) showed that areas with reduced or no chemical inputs had higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths than areas with conventional chemical applications. Using rotational mowing (Action 3966) demonstrated that grasslands managed by mowing strips in alternate years or leaving rotational areas uncut had higher abundance of butterflies and burnet moths than grasslands cut in full annually. Reducing farmland meadow management intensity (Action 22) found enhanced numbers of wild bees on meadows with delayed first cut and little agrochemical use.

query: What are the alternative management strategies to prescribed burning for maintaining open grassland habitats for butterflies?
relevant_summary:
Based on the action documents, several alternative management strategies to prescribed burning can be used to maintain open grassland habitats for butterflies:

Mowing regimes: Changing mowing regimes on grassland shows mixed results - prairies managed by haying had higher abundance of prairie specialist butterflies but lower abundance of generalist and migrant butterflies than prairies managed by burning (action ID 3945). Reducing cutting frequency on grassland to once per year shows that meadows cut once/year had higher species richness of butterflies and moths than meadows cut two or more times/year (action ID 3961).

Rotational mowing: Studies show that grasslands managed by mowing strips in alternate years or by leaving a rotational area uncut on each mow had higher abundance of butterflies and burnet moths than grasslands cut in full once or twice per year (action ID 3966). Rotational mowing benefitted 27 out of 67 butterfly species of conservation concern (action ID 3966).

Grazing management: Rotational grazing shows positive results with rotationally sheep-grazed and cattle-grazed grasslands having greater species richness of butterflies and burnet moths than continuously grazed or patch-burned grassland (action ID 3965). Reducing grazing intensity by seasonal removal of livestock also shows benefits - grasslands where cattle or sheep were removed in summer had higher abundance of butterflies and caterpillars than grasslands grazed throughout the summer (action ID 3960). However, increasing grazing intensity had negative effects - grasslands with more intensive grazing had lower abundance of adult butterflies and burnet moths than ungrazed or lightly grazed grasslands (action ID 3962).

Species-rich grassland maintenance: Maintaining species-rich, semi-natural grassland through various management approaches shows that semi-natural grasslands managed by extensive sheep, cattle or livestock grazing had similar or higher abundance of butterflies compared to annual mowing, rotational burning or unmanaged grasslands (action ID 3908).

General mowing: Mowing or cutting natural grasslands can provide an alternative to burning, though specific outcomes for butterflies were not detailed in this action (action ID 338).

relevant_summary: Based on documented studies, retaining or restoring habitat connectivity provides several benefits for butterfly populations. Studies found that restoring connectivity between habitat patches increased the abundance of Karner blue, high brown fritillary, small pearl-bordered fritillary, marsh fritillary and regal fritillary (action 3934). Well connected low quality habitat patches were more likely to retain Alcon large blue populations than less well connected patches, though connectivity did not affect occupancy of high quality patches (action 3832). Common buckeye were more likely to colonize farther away habitat patches when released on corridors of suitable habitat compared to unsuitable habitat, though this effect was not observed when released close to habitat patches (action 3832). Grassland strips providing nectar or shelter resources were more likely to be used by butterfly species than strips with no resources (action 3934). Well connected cleared patches within woodland had similar butterfly species richness to isolated cleared patches (action 3832).

query: Which grassland management techniques in UK agricultural settings are most beneficial for increasing butterfly and moth abundance?
relevant_summary:
Several grassland management techniques in UK agricultural settings have been shown to be beneficial for increasing butterfly and moth abundance. Reducing management intensity on permanent grasslands shows strong benefits, with six of 10 studies finding higher species richness of butterflies and moths in less intensively managed grasslands compared to conventionally managed grasslands (Action 3958). Three of four studies found that low-input or unfertilized, ungrazed grassland managed with a single cut had higher abundance of butterflies, micro-moths and declining macro-moths than intensively managed grassland (Action 3958). One UK before-and-after study found that after grazing was reduced and chemical application stopped, the total abundance of large moths and the abundance of five out of 23 butterfly species increased (Action 3958).

Rotational mowing techniques demonstrate significant benefits, with three of four studies finding that grasslands managed by mowing strips in alternate years, mowing and burning one half of the meadow each year, or mowing parts of a site at different times while leaving some areas uncut, had greater species richness and diversity of butterflies than grasslands cut in full once per year (Action 3966). Two controlled studies found that grasslands managed by mowing strips in alternate years or leaving a rotational area uncut on each mow had higher abundance of butterflies and burnet moths than grasslands cut in full once or twice per year (Action 3966). One UK study reported that two heath fritillary populations survived on rotationally mown grasslands while six populations went extinct on unmanaged grasslands (Action 3966).

Reducing chemical inputs also benefits butterfly and moth populations, with eight studies finding that areas managed with less frequent, reduced or no pesticide, herbicide, fertilizer or unspecified chemical input had greater species richness of adult butterflies and moths than areas with more frequent or conventional chemical applications (Action 3897). Six studies found higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths in areas with reduced chemical inputs (Action 3897).

Restoring arable land to permanent grassland shows promise, with three studies finding that 4-5-year-old created grasslands and abandoned cropland had greater species richness of butterflies, burnet moths and all moths than conventionally managed grassland or cultivated farms (Action 3929). Two studies found that grasslands established by sowing grasses, legumes and other non-woody, broadleaved plants had higher species richness and abundance of butterflies than grasslands established with grass-only mixes (Action 3929). One UK before-and-after study found that after adopting an Environmentally Sensitive Areas scheme including reverting arable land to permanent grassland, the species richness and abundance of large moths and five butterfly species increased (Action 3929).

Employing semi-natural habitat for rough grazing can also be beneficial, with one UK study finding that upland rough grassland managed by livestock grazing had greater species richness and higher abundance of butterflies than permanently or partially grazed improved grassland (Action 3944). Two UK studies found that fenland managed by cattle grazing for two years had higher abundance of large copper eggs and four of 13 butterfly species than unmanaged land (Action 3944).

**Increased Species Richness and Diversity**: Eight studies found that orchards, crop edges, farms, vineyards, replanted Douglas fir stands, coffee plantations and agricultural landscapes managed with less frequent, reduced or no pesticide, herbicide, fertilizer or unspecified chemical input had a greater species richness of adult butterflies and moths, or caterpillars, than areas with more frequent or conventional chemical applications (Action 3897). Two studies found that arable field margins and rice field banks which were not sprayed with the herbicide glyphosate had a greater species richness of butterflies than margins and banks sprayed once/year for 1-3 years (Action 3896). Seven studies found that organic arable farms had a greater species richness of butterflies, burnet moths and all moths than conventionally managed farms (Action 3907).

**Higher Abundance**: Six studies found that crop edges, farms, hay meadows, coffee plantations and agricultural landscapes managed with less frequent, reduced or no pesticide, insecticide, fungicide, herbicide, fertilizer or unspecified chemical input had a higher abundance of adult butterflies and moths, or caterpillars, than areas with more frequent or conventional chemical applications (Action 3897). Three studies found that arable field margins and rice field banks which were not sprayed with the herbicide glyphosate had a higher total abundance of butterflies, and of meadow brown and large copper specifically, than margins and banks sprayed once/year for 1-3 years (Action 3896). Seven studies found that organic arable farms had a greater abundance of butterflies, burnet moths, and all moths than conventionally managed farms, and that butterfly abundance increased with time since farms had been converted to organic management (Action 3907). One study found that margins next to water bodies managed with restrictions on fertilizer and pesticide use had a greater abundance of moths than conventionally managed margins (Action 3894).

**Long-term Effects**: The benefits may be cumulative over time, as one study found that species richness was not affected by the number of pesticide applications in the year of study, only in the previous three years (Action 3897).

query: What are some evidence-based alternatives to prescribed burning for managing disturbance in forests to benefit butterflies?
relevant_summary:
Based on the available evidence from action documents, several alternatives to prescribed burning have been shown to benefit butterflies in forest management:

Clearing or opening patches in forests (Action 3938) showed positive effects for butterflies, with studies finding that cleared patches had greater species richness of butterflies than unmanaged patches, coppiced woodland, or closed canopy forest. Five studies found that cleared patches, often combined with coppicing and grazing, had higher abundance of butterflies generally and specific species including chequered blue, woodland brown, high brown fritillary, and small pearl-bordered fritillary than before management or compared to unmanaged areas. A European review reported that clearing small patches in forests benefitted 19 out of 67 butterfly species of conservation concern.

Thinning trees within forests (Action 3940) demonstrated benefits, with four studies finding that coniferous woodland thinned along with either prescribed burning, mulching, or nearby felling had greater species richness and higher abundance of butterflies than unmanaged woodland or before management, measured one to four years after management.

Selective or reduced impact logging (Action 3867) showed some positive results, with studies finding that forests managed by reduced impact logging had similar or higher species richness and abundance of butterflies compared to primary forest, though community composition differed from pristine forest.

Harvesting groups of trees or using thinning instead of clearcutting (Action 3868) showed that thinning resulted in higher macro-moth species richness than patch-cutting or clearcutting, with richness similar to unharvested forest.

Shelterwood harvesting instead of clearcutting (Action 3871) demonstrated that moth species richness recovered faster after shelterwood harvesting than after group selection harvesting or clearcutting.

Managing woodland edges for maximum habitat heterogeneity (Action 3942) showed increased species richness of butterflies, diurnal moths and bumblebees two years after felling woodland edges and thinning adjacent forest compared to before management or unmanaged edges.

Creating young plantations within mature woodland (Action 3941) found that pearl-bordered fritillary and small pearl-bordered fritillary populations were more likely to persist for up to 20 years in woodlands with larger areas of young plantations than in mature woodland.
